response.answer_text: I've just answered a similar question so I would like to replicate that one here. The reopening of school will be set on schedule when there is no more infectious figures or there are only figures due to the input from other countries. Take Shanghai as an example, our local infectious figures have not increased since the late March. So the reopening schedule has been raised at Apr.15. According to education bureau of Shanghai, graduating grades will first come back to school at Apr. 27 including ninth grade and twelfth grade. Other grades of junior high school will come back at May. 6. Grade 10 and 11will be back at May. 18. Graduate students and undergraduate students will come back in different groups from Apr. 27 to Jun. 10 and the specific date is decided by universities themselves. However, kindergarten and elementary school may not reopen this semester since those young kids face greater threat from the current situation. I'm a sophomore at Fudan University in Shanghai, and most of our graduate students have come back to school up to today. These two photos were taken on campus this week. The materials in the first picture are distributed to each student by our university, conpromising tissues, fruits, disinfection water, vitamin pills, face mask, and brochure containing precautious about dormitory life. The words in the second picture means "Welcome back school!".

UGC To Release Guidelines For Colleges, Universities Next Week The University Grants Commission (UGC) on Saturday said that it will release the guidelines for academic measures to be taken by colleges and universities for the current and the next academic session next week. New Semester Time Tables 2020 - 2021 After Lockdown New Delhi: The University Grants Commission (UGC) on Saturday said that it will release the guidelines for academic measures to be taken by colleges and universities for the current and the next academic session next week. The UGC's guidelines will be based on the suggestions given by the two committees which were formed earlier. These committees have submitted their reports to the Commission. "UGC constituted two committees to look into the issues being faced by the universities and colleges regarding teaching-learning processes, examinations, admissions, academic calendar and other related issues in view of the COVID-19 pandemic and countrywide lockdown, to avoid academic loss and take appropriate measures for the future of students," reads an official statement from UGC. The first committee under the chairmanship of Professor RC Kuhad, former member UGC and Vice-Chancellor, Central University of Haryana, was given the responsibility to look into the issues related to examinations and academic calendar. The second committee under the chairmanship of Professor Nageshwar Rao, Vice-Chancellor, Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) was asked to look into issues related to promoting online education. The second panel has suggested that universities should conduct online exams if they have the infrastructure and means or wait for the lockdown to get over and then decide a date for pen-and-paper examinations," a source said.
